title: 109_s2695
content: The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 aims to make research funded by the Federal Government accessible to the public through the internet. It defines a Federal agency as an Executive agency under section 105 of title 5, United States Code. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 requires Federal agencies with over $100,000,000 in research expenditures to develop a public access policy for research papers funded by the government. This policy includes submitting final manuscripts of research papers to the agency, incorporating peer review changes, and replacing the manuscript with the published version. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 mandates that research papers funded by the Federal Government must be made publicly accessible online within 6 months of publication in peer-reviewed journals. This includes submitting final manuscripts, incorporating peer review changes, and replacing them with the published version. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 requires free online public access to final peer-reviewed manuscripts within 6 months of publication, an online bibliography of accessible research papers, and long-term preservation of published research findings in a digital repository maintained by the Federal agency. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 mandates that research works funded or conducted by Federal agencies must be stored in a digital repository with free public access, interoperability, and long-term preservation. Researchers' works in the public domain must be marked as such when published and made immediately available online. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 requires research funded by Federal agencies to be marked as public domain when published and made available online. It also emphasizes the use of Government licenses for manuscript reproduction. Exclusions from the policy include laboratory notes and classified research. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 mandates that research funded by Federal agencies be made public online. Exclusions from the policy include laboratory notes, classified research, and works generating revenue for authors. Nothing in the Act affects rights under patent or copyright law. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 mandates public online access to federally funded research, excluding revenue-generating works and classified research. The Act does not affect rights under patent or copyright law. Federal agencies must submit an annual report on the effectiveness of the public access policy to Congress. The Federal Research Public Access Act of 2006 requires federal agencies to provide free online access to research papers funded by them. The annual report to Congress must include an assessment of the policy's effectiveness, a list of published papers, papers made available online, and the time lag between publication and online availability. The Federal agency is required to provide free online access to research papers funded by them. The agency must include in their annual report a list of published papers, papers available online, and the time lag between publication and online availability. The agency must make this information available to the public by posting it on their website.
